title: Composite Reactive Block for Heat Transformer System and Improvement of System Performance
abstract: A new process for fabricating composite reactive block composed of the expanded graphite and reactive salt for the heat transformer system is proposed. The suitable condition to expand the graphite is found to be over 700°C for 15 min, and the reactive salt is impregnated by immersing the expanded graphite in the reactive salt solution. The performance of the heat transformer using the composite reactive block is accordingly simulated. It is found that the gas volume has quite important effect on the matching of the reacting rates and consequently it affects the system performance. The system COP is higher in the case of small gas volume, in particular when the driven temperature is high.
full_text:
Journal of Chemical Engineering of Japan, V ol. 40, No. 13, pp. 1275–1280, 2007 Research Paper

Received on May 14, 2007; accepted on August 9, 2007. Cor-
respondence concerning this article should be addressed to
P. Zhang (E-mail address: zhangp@sjtu.edu.cn).
Presented at International Symposium on Innovative Materials
for Processes in Energy Systems, IMPRES, Kyoto, October,
2007.
Composite Reactive Block for Heat Transformer System and
Improvement of System Performance
Peng Z HANG , Cheng W ANG and Ruzhu W ANG
Institute of Refrigeration and Cryogenics,
Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, 200240, China
Keywords : Heat Transformer, Solid–Gas Reaction, Composite Reactive Block, Gas V olume
A new process for fabricating composite reactive block composed of the expanded graphite and reac-
tive salt for the heat transformer system is proposed. The suitable condition to expand the graphite is
found to be over 700
°C for 15 min, and the reactive salt is impregnated by immersing the expanded
graphite in the reactive salt solution. The performance of the heat transformer using the composite reac-
tive block is accordingly simulated. It is found that the gas volume has quite important effect on the
matching of the reacting rates and consequently it affects the system performance. The system COP is
higher in the case of small gas volume, in particular when the driven temperature is high.
Introduction
With the development of economy, the environ-
ment protection and the energy conservation become
the focus of public attention. These concerns urge the
researchers to explore the renewable energy source,
such as solar energy and geothermal energy, and to
recover the exhausted energy, which is mainly in the
form of industrial waste heat. However, the wide and
effective utilization of these heat sources is limited
because their temperatures are always very low. Thus,
it is considered that more valuable use can be realized
by lifting the temperatures of these heat sources.
Though the heat transformer based on solid–gas
reaction (for example, chloride-ammonia) can be used
for uplifting the temperature, the system COP is small.
It has been proved by the experimental and theoretical
analysis that the system COP is limited by the poor
performance of the heat and mass transfer (Sun et al.,
1995; Menard et al ., 2005). Many researchers have
proposed the reactive block with enhanced heat and/or
mass transfer performance. As in most cases, the sys-
tem performance is limited by the heat transfer proc ess,
and only when the system pressure is low enough, e.g.,
lower than 0.01 MPa, system performance is limited
by the mass transfer process (Mbaye et al ., 1998). Lu
et al. (1996) proposed a procedure to fabricate the re-
active block (IMPEX) with enhanced heat transfer per-
formance. However, in Lu’s procedure, vacuum dry-
ing is needed, which is obviously not desirable.
Oliveira (2006) proposed another procedure with no
need of vacuum drying to fabricate the reactive block,
which was proved with enhanced heat transfer perform-
ance. But it seems that the distribution of the reactive
salt in the reactive block is not uniform in some cases.
In the single-stage heat transformer, there are gen-
erally two kinds of the reactive blocks in the two reac-
tors. Gas space exists in the system and the system
performance is influenced by the gas volume which is
the free space above reactive blocks. However, this is
not well understood, yet.
In this paper, a new procedure for fabricating the
reactive block is proposed and accordingly the test is
carried out. The influences of the gas volume on the
matching of the reacting rates and the system perform-
ance are theoretically analyzed.
1. Reactive Block
1.1 Fabrication procedure of the reactive block
The reactive block is made of the expanded graph-
ite and reactive salt. The new procedure proposed to
fabricate the reactive block is described as following:
the graphite is expanded at a set expansion tempera-
ture for a certain duration; and the expanded graphite
is compressed into matrix; the expanded graphite ma-
trix is immersed into the salt solution; and the reactive
block is then formed by drying the expanded graphite
matrix impregnated with the salt in the environment
of inert gas, e.g., nitrogen gas. The apparent density of
the expanded graphite matrix is the mass in a unit vol-
ume, which can be controlled by compressing proper
amount of the expanded graphite into a fixed volume.
1276 JOURNAL OF CHEMICAL ENGINEERING OF JAPAN
1.2 Test results of the reactive block
In the reactive block, the reactive salt is impreg-
nated into the expanded graphite. Therefore, the ex-
pansion of the graphite, which is affected by the ex-
pansion temperature and expansion duration, plays
quite crucial role for the reactive block. It is shown in
Figure 1  that the apparent density of the expanded
graphite varies little when the expansion temperature
is over 500 °C and the expansion duration is over
15 min. The structure of the expanded graphite is fur-
ther observed with SEM (Scanning Electronic Micro-
scope).
Figure 2  shows the structure of the expanded
graphite. It is seen from the figure that the shapes of
the expanded graphite are similar and look like a
“worm” at temperature over 300 °C, as shown in Fig-
ures 2(a) and (b), which indicates that the graphite has
been fully expanded. The graphite still remains flake
shape when the expansion temperature is below 300 °C.
The completely expanded graphite will help the im-
pregnation of the salt. Therefore, the expansion tem-
perature and the expansion duration are taken as 700 °C
and 15 min to make sure the graphite is expanded com-
pletely. The apparent density of the fully expanded
graphite is estimated to be about 10 kg/m
3, and the pore
size is measured with the nitrogen gas adsorption, and
the results are shown in Table 1.
The expanded graphite matrix is made by com-
pressing the powder into block, and used for the heat
transfer enhancement. Han et al. (1998) measured the
thermal conductivity of the expanded graphite matrix
with different apparent density. It is shown that the
thermal conductivity increases sharply with the appar-
ent density of the expanded graphite block. Compared
with the thermal conductivity of salt powder of about
0.1–0.2 W/m/K (Wang et al ., 2006), the heat transfer
performance can be significantly enhanced with the
expanded graphite matrix. However, it should be men-
tioned that with the increase of the apparent density of
the expanded graphite matrix, the permeability de-
creases a lot (Goetz et al ., 1997), which may lead to
the mass transfer problem, in particular in the case of
synthesis at low pressure. Therefore, the apparent den-
sity of the expanded graphite matrix should not be too
large to deteriorate the mass transfer. The apparent
density of the expanded graphite matrix in this paper
to make the reactive block is estimated to be 200–300
kg/m
3, and the thermal conductivity along the direc-
tion perpendicular to the compression is measured to
be around 12 W/m/K.
The reactive block is made by impregnation of the
salt into the expanded graphite matrix. In this test, salt
of SrCl
2 as an example is impregnated into the ex-
panded graphite. The structure of the block after the
impregnation of the salt is observed with BEC (back-
scattered electron composition) and analyzed by EDS
(energy X-ray dispersive spectrometry). The results are
shown in Figure 3 . The bright area in the image is the

VOL. 40 NO. 13 2007 1277
salt, and the shadow area is the expanded graphite. It
is clear that the block is impregnated with the salt,
which is also confirmed from EDS. The weight frac-
tion of the salt in the composite reactive block shown
in Figure 3 is estimated to be about 40%. With the in-
crease of the salt concentration, more salt is impreg-
nated into the expanded graphite matrix. Therefore, the
weight fraction of the salt in the reactive block in-
creases. It is also seen from Figure 3 that the salt in the
reactive block is uniformly distributed, and rests be-
tween the flakes of the expanded graphite. The salt in
the reactive block is in the form of small crystals, which
is in favor of the reaction between the salt and gas.
Because the salt is separated by the flakes of the ex-
panded graphite, the agglomeration can be avoided.
The SEM image of the composite reactive block
made by the above procedure and that of IMPEX
(Mauran et al ., 2001; Olives and Mauran, 2001) are
shown in Figure 4 . The area surrounded by black line
in the two images is the space between flakes of ex-
panded graphite and is filled with salt. Comparing the
images in Figure 4, it is found that the present com-
posite reactive block has similar micro-scale structure
to the block IMPEX. The small difference between two
images is due to different salts impregnated in two
blocks. Since the thermal conductivity and gas perme-
ability of the reactive block are mainly determined by
the micro-scale structure. It is believed that the ther-
mal conductivity and the gas permeability of the block
made by the procedure proposed in this paper should
be close to those of the IMPEX block, which are in the
range of 5 –20 W/m/K and 10
–15–10–16 m2, respectively.
Therefore, the heat and mass transfer can be enhanced,
and consequently the system performance can be im-
proved by applying the composite reactive block to the
heat transformer. The following section devotes to the
analysis of the system performance of heat transformer
using the composite reactive block.
2. System Performance Analysis and Improve-
ment
System performance is analyzed for single-stage
heat transformer, which is composed of two reactors
filled with the composite reactive blocks. And the space
in the system excluding the composite reactive blocks
is named as the gas volume. The principle of the sys-
tem operation is shown in Figure 5. The salts are MnCl
2
and CaCl 2 and the reactive gas is NH 3. The system op-
eration is composed of two processes: the high pres-
sure process and the low pressure process. During the
low pressure process at P
L, the MnCl 2·6NH3 decom-
poses at TM and CaCl 2·2NH3 synthesis at TL; and dur-
ing the high pressure process at PH, CaCl 2·4NH3 de-
composes at TM and the MnCl 2·2NH3 synthesis at TH.
The temperature lifting is realized by the synthesis of
MnCl
2 at the high pressure.
It is assumed that the process stops when the re-
action degree reaches 0.9 in the synthesis process or
0.1 in the decomposition process. Lumped parameters,
such as, the temperatures and the reaction degrees in
the two reactors, the amount and temperature of gas,
and the system pressure are calculated by the follow-
ing equations.
The temperature of the reactive block is described

where the subscripts ‘syn’ and ‘dec’ represent the re-
actors undergoing process of synthesis and decompo-
sition, respectively. Thus, T
dec equals Ts in the reactor
filled with CaCl 2 during high pressure process; while
it equals Ts in the reactor with MnCl 2 during low pres-
sure process.
With Eqs. (1) –(5), system operation processes are
simulated in the cases of two different gas volumes. In
the simulation, the higher temperature reactor with
MnCl
2 exchanges heat with a heat source of 120 °C.
The analytical results are shown in Figures 6 –10.
To analyze the influence of the gas volume on the
system performance, the variation of the reacting rates
in the two reactors and the variation of the system pres-
sure with time are calculated by taking the driven waste
heat temperature T
M of 120 °C, if not specified. And
the system performance is compared in the cases of
two gas volumes: small gas volume and large gas vol-
ume representing the system with the gas volume as
0.5 and 5 times of the volume of the total composite
reactive blocks, respectively. And the volumes of the
CaCl
2 and MnCl 2 composite reactive blocks of 0.25 m 3
and 0.12 m 3 are used in this study.
The variation of the reacting rate with the time is
shown in Figure 6. It is seen from Figure 6(a) that the
reacting rate of CaCl
2 is larger than that of MnCl 2,
which indicates that the reacting rates of MnCl 2 and
CaCl2 do not match at all in the case of large gas vol-
ume. However, the reacting rates of CaCl 2 and MnCl 2
in the system with small gas volume are nearly the
same, as shown in Figure 6(b). The reacting rate of
Fig. 6 V ariation of the reacting rates of CaCl 2 and MnCl 2:
(a) large gas volume; (b) small gas volume
Fig. 7 Variation of the reaction degrees of CaCl 2 and
MnCl2: (a) large gas volume; (b) small gas volume
VOL. 40 NO. 13 2007 1279
MnCl2 is larger in the system with small gas volume.
Since the synthesis process of MnCl 2 is an exothermic
process, the increased reacting rate of MnCl 2 in the
case of small gas volume will lead to higher tempera-
ture of MnCl
2.
The operation cycle is assumed to start at t = 0
when the initial reaction degree of CaCl 2 is 1, and the
initial reaction degree of MnCl 2 is 0. It is found that it
takes less time for the system with large gas volume to
finish one cycle. In a period of 5000 s, as shown in
Figures 7(a) and (b), the system with large gas volume
finishes 4 cycles; while the system with small gas vol-
ume only finishes 2 cycles. The reaction degrees of
CaCl
2 in the cases of large and small gas volumes both
change from 0.1 to 0.9. The reaction degree of MnCl 2
in the system with large gas volume changes from 0.3
to 0.5, while it changes from 0.1 to 0.9 in the system
with small gas volume. It is shown in Figure 6 that the
reacting rates of MnCl
2 and CaCl 2 match well in the
case of small gas volume. While in the case of large
gas volume, the reacting rates are unmatched. There-
fore, it is concluded that the gas volume in the system
has adjusting effect on the balance of the reacting rates.
Although the synthesis rate of MnCl
2 increases in the
case of small gas volume, the decomposition rate of
CaCl
2 decreases as shown in Figure 6. Since the varia-
tion of the reaction degrees of CaCl 2 in the cases of
large and small gas volume are the same, the system
cycle period in the case of small gas volume is longer,
and the system COP is larger, due to the larger varia-
tion of the reaction degree of MnCl
2.
The variations of the temperature of MnCl 2 and
the system pressure during the system operation are
shown in Figure 8. The system pressure changes dras-

tem pressure with time: (a) the temperature of
MnCl

Fig. 9 Influences of the gas volume on the system power

rate. The system pressure in the system with small gas
volume changes more than that in the system with large
gas volume. However, during most periods of the sys-
tem operation, the system pressure in the system with
small gas volume keeps nearly constant, which is due
to the matched reacting rates in the system. Conse-
quently, the temperature of MnCl
2 changes, as shown
in Figure 8(a).

The influences of gas volume on the system power
and system COP, which are calculated by Eq. (6) for
different cases, are shown in Figure 9. It is found that
with the increase of gas volume, the system power and
system COP decrease, especially in the case of higher
driven temperature. The large system power in the case
of small gas volume, in spite of long cycle time, is due
1280
to the fact that the temperature in reactor with MnCl 2
is higher. However, it should be pointed out that the
result is obtained under the conditions studied in this
paper. There may be other factors that have influences
on system performance, such as initial charging pres-
sure of NH
3 and system configuration. The detailed
effects of these influential factors on the system per-
formance will be studied in the future.
With the increase of the driven waste heat tem-
perature T
M, the decomposition rate of CaCl 2 increases,
consequently, the synthesis rate of MnCl 2 also in-
creases. The adjusting effect of smaller gas volume on
the balance of the reacting rates is stronger. Therefore,
the synthesis rate of MnCl
2 in system with small gas
volume is larger than that in system with large gas vol-
ume, and the maximum temperature of MnCl
2 in sys-
tem with small gas volume is higher, as shown in Fig-
ure 10. Therefore, the gas volume can have the adjust-
ing effect for system performance improvement.
Conclusions
A new procedure to fabricate the reactive block
composed of the expanded graphite and reactive salt
is proposed and tested. The suitable expansion condi-
tion for the expanded graphite is found to be as 700 °C
for 15 min. The reactive block is fabricated by impreg-
nation of the salt into the expanded graphite matrix
with no need of vacuum drying. And the test results
show that the reactive salt distributes uniformly in the
expanded graphite which is in favor of the reaction.
The system performance of the single-stage heat
transformer with the composite reactive blocks is simu-
lated by putting the emphasis on the influence of the
gas volume. It is found that the reacting rates of two
composite reactive blocks match in the case of small
gas volume, which leads to the higher temperature of
MnCl
2 and rather constant system pressure during sys-
tem operation. The system cycle in the case of small
gas volume is longer; while the system COP is larger.
Acknowledgements
This research is jointly supported by Shanghai Pujiang Pro-
gram (06PJ14061) and Shanghai Municipal Science and Technol-
ogy Committee (06SR07106).
Nomenclature
A = heat transfer area [m 2]
a = constant [1/s]
b = constant
Cp = heat capacity [J/g/K]
H = enthalpy change of the reaction [J/mol]
m = mass of the salt [g]
N = molar amount of the salt [mol]
n = gas amount [mol]
P = system pressure [MPa]
Peq = equilibrium pressure [MPa]
Q = heat added to and exported out of system [J]
R = gas constant
S = entropy change of the reaction [J/mol/K]
SBET = specific pore surface area by BET [m 2/g]
Tc = constraint temperature [ °C]
Tg = temperature of gas [ °C]
Ts = temperature in the reactor [ °C]
t = time [s]
U = heat transfer coefficient [W/m 2/K]
V = gas volume [m 3]
VT = specific pore volume [cm 3/g]
x = reaction degree
